captions.text:
I like to think I know my stuff when it comes
to RPGs. But just mention "Falcom" to me and

I curl up into a ball. Trying to trace the
lineage of the Legend of Heroes series, the

Dragon Slayer series, the Ys series, and how
they all twist and turn throughout early Japanese

PC hardware and re-re-re-revisions of untranslated
versions... It's enough to make my brain run

out my ear. But still, I found myself with
a copy of The Legend of Heroes: Trails in

the Sky, and... man, if there's more like
this to be enjoyed, I must be missing out.

I can't think of the last time a game just
completely blindsided me like this, but I

get the feeling it was Mana Khemia. And I
like being blindsided by awesomeness. I'm
just lacking historical context, for once.

So instead of yammering on about what the
game was, I'll yammer on about what it is:

an RPG that has a bit of tactical movement,
a bit of spellcasting, a lot of turn manipulation

and timing considerations, non-random battles
engaged by approaching enemies on the world

map... honestly, if you were to run down a
list of "things I like in an RPG," Trails

in the Sky would hit at least 75% of them.
Also to its credit: a story that's actually

quite intriguing. In a world where a recent
scientific breakthrough has simultaneously

outfitted adventurers with magic and ships
with air-travel capability, political unrest

brews. But before any of that gets particularly
interesting, we find a girl home alone, waiting

for her adventurer father to return from a
mission... exactly the kind of scene where

we get the feeling someone's about to become
an orphan and doesn't know it yet. But not

only does the old man show up, but he's carrying
a wounded boy! Several years later, this kid

of mysterious origin has become a well-adjusted
part of the family. So well-adjusted that

when he begins to THINK he's not well-adjusted,
it's a big deal. I mean, when in JRPGs does
THAT ever happen?

The gameplay of Trails in the Sky toes the
line of "overcomplicated" without ever really

stepping over. Sure, you're dealing with seven
different flavors of crystal shards dropped

from enemies, which can be crafted into gems,
which can be installed in each warrior's clockwork

stat-improvement mabob (technical term), or
just hocked for cash. As members of the local

Bracers guild, basically a one-stop shop for
heroes for hire, you'll be taking jobs and

helping out the townsfolk, which usually involves
getting into RPGish fights and plot exposition.

Which is fine! Especially since the translation
and localization feels very comfortable, not

trying to be overly formal or colloquial,
without undermining the "world on the brink

of technological breakthrough" setting. And
while the vocal work is a bit shaky - let's

face it, it's tacked onto a game that didn't
really need it in the first place - it knows

not to get in the way of what feels like a
really good PS1-era adventure.

And then the battle. You've got a bar along
the left side, indicating turn order, and

with the occasional icon indicating which
turns are going to get guaranteed critical

hits or some free healing or other beneficial
effects. Trick is, those bonuses are locked

to that particular turn, not whoever's taking
it, so if you manage to knock out the enemy

that WOULD have benefited such that an ally
moves into that slot, they get the boon. It's

another wrinkle of depth in a system that
incorporates a grid-based tactical layout

in instanced combat, with all sorts of spells
to obtain and equip by loading quartz into

your Orbment Augement McGuffin. Oh, and if
you dish and receive enough damage over the

course of several battles, you can spend that
CP to break the turn order and throw an extra-beefy

attack in where needed. Look at Estelle go.
Like a low-res Lilly Kane. If you've been

struggling to break the golden dome over Falcom's
offerings... well, you're not alone, especially

in the West. But XSeed took a flyer on Trails
in the Sky, and I for one applaud the effort.
The gaming world needs more Minori Kushieda-types.
